speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We will hear argument next in Case 14-419, Luis v. United States. Mr. Srebnick.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What do you do about Monsanto?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right. So what is the logic that says it doesn't violate the Sixth Amendment if it's tainted funds, but it does if it's untainted funds?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But, Mr. Srebnick, I mean, compare two situations. One is the one that Monsanto talked about where, yeah, a bank robber goes in and he has a pile of money now. And Monsanto says, you know, even though he wants to use that money to pay for an attorney, too bad. Now a bank robber goes in, he has a pile of money, he puts it into a separate bank account, he uses that bank account to pay his rent, to pay other expenses, and he uses the money that would have gone for the rent and other expenses to pay a lawyer. Why should the two cases be treated any differently for Sixth Amendment purposes?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but is -- doesn't it make sense the -- the sort of substitution rule? I mean, if you've got $10 million in drug activity -- money and you had $5 million, and you spent $10 million, you can't say, you know, oh, I spent the drug money, you can't touch the $5 million. It seems to me that's what the statute is doing when it says whatever it's a reasonable substitute or assets substituted for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but I -- I thought the Chief Justice's question was slightly different. I don't know if you were privileged to hear the exciting argument yesterday on tainted assets. (Laughter.) Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But, you know, there are degree -- there are degrees of taint. Can you -- can you follow -- can you follow the assets? So just to say "tainted" or "untainted," it's a -- it's a more difficult question than that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, let me go back to Justice -- Justice Kagan's question and ask it in -- in a different way. So you -- we have two brothers and -- twin brothers, and they rob a bank. They get $10,000. They split it up, $5,000 each. And on that very same day, it happens to be their birthday, and their rich uncle comes and gives each of them $5,000 as a birthday present. So they go out to party, and one of them -- and they both spend $5,000 partying. One of them spends the money from the bank robbery. The other one spends the money Alderson Reporting Company that was given to them by their rich uncle. And your position is that the one who spent the money from the so-called "tainted assets," the money from the bank robbery, is entitled to use the remaining $5,000 to hire an attorney, but the other one is out of luck?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What sense does that make?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So the law -- you want this Court to say spend the bank robbery money first. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's -- that's your position?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How do -- I -- I don't know how these things actually work. I mean, the defendant obviously has daily expenses, and -- and that the government's freeze order apparently goes beyond the money she has. What, does she get an allowance or -- or something?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So -- so if her -- putting aside lawyers, if her daughter's tuition bill comes due, she can't pay that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But she can surely pay the rent or the mortgage?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I have the -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is it your position the government could prevent payment for the tuition but not for the counsel?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So the answer is you can -- the government can stop the tuition payment but not the payment to counsel?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So you really don't have a statutory argument. You're making a Sixth Amendment argument because if it were a statutory argument, it would be you can -- you can restrain -- you can't restrain untainted assets.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I guess I'm -- I understand what you're going to say because I read your brief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But the logic of your argument would suggest that you can't freeze untainted assets for anything, because you're saying the government has no property right to it. It's untainted. It's your money; it's not their money until they secure a judgment. And so the logic of your position would be, I think, they can't restrain untainted assets, period, constitutionally or statutorily.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I know you don't because it's very nice that you limit it. But once we announce a rule, we have to carry it to its logical conclusion. And if the rule is it's untainted assets and it belongs to me, how do we then limit it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you said that this -- this is her property. If it's tainted, you say she doesn't own it, it's not her money. But if it's untainted, it is her money. So I think Justice Sotomayor has asked a fair question. Isn't the logic of your position that the untainted assets can be used without restraint for whatever she wants to use it for?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What if --  what if the woman is a devout Muslim and she --  she makes a --  an Alderson Reporting Company annual trip to Mecca every year? Wouldn't she have a constitutional right to use the money for that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, she has an immediate need to go to Mecca. I mean, if she doesn't get it now, she's not going to be able to fulfill what she regards as a religious obligation. I don't know how you can limit your -- your principle to the Sixth Amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Srebnick, this goes back, I think, to the Chief Justice's first question. It seems that the distinction that you're making is one that the Court explicitly rejected in Monsanto. In other words, the Court said the Sixth Amendment here is the exact same thing as the First Amendment. It even used that example that Justice Scalia gave, or that general example. And --  and so it goes back to the Chief Justice's question in --  in the sense of there's a very powerful intuition behind your argument, but it's a powerful intuition that was explicitly rejected by us. And --  and this case doesn't seem to present any different circumstances than that one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yeah, but your -- your earlier argument was you have a constitutional right to establish that it isn't drug money. That was your whole answer to Justice Scalia.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'm talking about the rule that you're proposing.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I guess you're -- I think this may be Justice Sotomayor's point. Your argument, you're distinguishing tainted and untainted assets, and I understand that. I just don't understand that if you can freeze the assets despite the Sixth Amendment when they're tainted, I don't understand why it's not the same rule when they're untainted. You may have -- may have statutory arguments, you -- but if you have arguments, it has nothing to do with the constitutional right to counsel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, what if -- what if the prosecution brings a case for crime X and wins that case, and it imposes a fine that takes away all of the defendant's assets, and then the prosecution brings another case for crime Y, would you be arguing that the fine had to make an exception for the defense of crime Y?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What's the difference?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The Sixth Amendment only -- only protects your money up until the point where there's a judgment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But in --  in this case, there was a finding of probable cause.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So you want us to make a distinction between probable cause and a judgment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I might just be repeating myself, but --  but I thought that, again, that distinction was the one specifically rejected in Alderson Reporting Company Monsanto. I mean, Monsanto could have said Caplin & Drysdale is different because it's postconviction. But Monsanto refused to say that. Monsanto said the same rule that applies postconviction ought to apply upon a finding of probable cause.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: The problem with this argument is that as a matter of economics and --  and common sense, money is fungible. To say if the --  if the so-called tainted money has been spent, and what's left is the untainted money, it doesn't make a difference which --  you know, which pot has been spent and which pot hasn't been spent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, yes, but then there's -- that's all sorts of complicated rules in those areas. I mean, let's -- suppose you have -- and none of that necessarily applies here. Suppose you have the situation where what's at stake is money that's going to be used for restitution, all right? So at the beginning of the case, the question is whether the defendant can spend that money to hire the attorney of the defendant's choice, which is certainly a very powerful interest, or whether that money, at the end of the case if there is a conviction, is going to go to the victims. So how do you -- how do you try to accommodate those two interests?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So your answer is that the Alderson Reporting Company defendant's right to hire counsel of choice takes precedence over the rights of the victims, and you would say that no matter how strong the proof is?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Until there's -- until there is a verdict?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That seems to me not a very -- I don't know -- not a very persuasive line. You're relying on property law. What you're saying is the government can take away all your money if it's tainted, if there is probable cause to believe that it's tainted, right? It can take away all of your money if there is a judgment. But it can't take away all of your money if there's simply probable cause to believe that you're going to owe this money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Your crime. That seems to me a very -- I don't know, not -- not -- an evanescent line. I -- I don't know why the Sixth Amendment case is -- the property case is -- is stronger in one situation than the other, but I'm not sure that the Alderson Reporting Company Sixth Amendment case is any stronger.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's right. It's property law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're complaining about property law, not the Sixth Amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I know this is not part of the question asked, but I know that it -- it's suggested in the fringes of the briefs. How does the district court ensure that she doesn't use every penny Alderson Reporting Company for defense costs when the district court thinks that that's not reasonable, for example?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But you're not -- you're not looking for CJA rates, are you?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I didn't think so. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, we have a new statute. made a difference between -- and still does -- between tainted and untainted.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: This section came later, and it says substitute property.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But Congress seemed to have singled out these banking frauds and healthcare frauds for special treatment, so they're not governed by the general forfeiture statute, which makes the distinction between tainted and untainted. They seem to want to come down very hard on these two crimes. So why would we interpret -- was it 1345? -- as doing nothing, as being controlled essentially by 853?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Dreeben.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that was said in the context of the government's submission that there's a difference between tainted and untainted, right? Your --  your argument in Monsanto focused on the tainted aspects of the proceeds.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why is that the principle? The principle --  they're talking about money that doesn't belong to the defendant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It belongs to Smith or Jones of the bank. Now, let's try that principle in a case where it's the defendant's money. The principle is that the government, without proving that he's guilty of any crime beyond a reasonable doubt, can take all his money. Oh, because he might be fined. I've never heard of such a principle, frankly. I've just never heard of it. Now, if there is some case that says --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Sixth Amendment or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So --  now I can imagine --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I can go from there and find interests on both sides, da, da, da.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I --  I understood that. I just wanted to try it with the facts here. I mean, the first principle is if, in fact, the defendant has somebody else's money that he's taken unlawfully, and he has to give it up at the end of the trial, we can make him give it up at the beginning to make sure it's there. Now let's try it with the facts here. If a defendant has some money, which maybe he will have to pay in a fine, what we'll do is we'll take all his money away before he's been convicted beyond a reasonable doubt. Okay. That's the difference in the propositions. Alderson Reporting Company And I'm saying it's pretty hard for me to think in a country which says that before he's convicted, you have to release him on bail except in unusual circumstances, that nonetheless, you can take all his money away so he can't hire a lawyer. I know that's a little simpleminded, but nonetheless, that seems fairly basic. I don't know where it comes from.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's correct. That is the principle, and now we make a number of exceptions. And one exception is if you think he's going to -- I mean, I can think of exceptions where we do keep people in jail. That is, of course, right. And -- and here, what they're saying, I think, in essence is, let's try and think of an exception for this one. Pretty hard. And anyway, if there is one, what he wants to use the money for is to make sure he has a lawyer. It's called the Sixth Amendment. All right. Now, there we are. That's where I -- at this moment in my mind, that's where the case Alderson Reporting Company is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I think -- I think that's a -- what you say is, look, this is equivalent to the case where we keep the guy in jail because he might run away. That's your point. That's not a bad point. So I have on that on one side, and I have on the other side that he'd like to have a lawyer which is a Sixth Amendment right. So I have a suggestion that I want you to focus on. The suggestion is -- let's read this statute in light of what you've said, that there is an interest on your side and there is a constitutional amendment on Alderson Reporting Company the other side. Why can't we read this statute to say they accommodate those interests in this way? If they're going to run away from -- with the property, then the court has the authority to enjoin the alienation or disposition of property, say tainted, then you can ask for a restraining order to prohibit the prohibition, not just of the tainted property but also of property of equivalent value. If I read that without knowing the background, I would say a lot of cases come up where you get TROs, where they're not precise because you don't know exactly what property you're talking about. So what do you think about reading this statute to avoid the constitutional question to say the TRO means TRO? And a TRO means where there's some property out there and it may be tainted, mixed up with the untainted, you can get a TRO on the whole thing. You have to have a speedy hearing. He has to be represented. And your purpose of that is to separate the two kinds of assets. That seems to me to work for the purpose, and it also avoids the constitutional question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Do you really --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But what is it that confines your --  your rationale to a specific area? It seems to me that if the government prevails in this case, every State in the union, every locality could say that in the event of assault and battery, malicious -- malicious mischief, drunk --  an accident caused by drunk driving, any crime involving a bodily injury, that the government is entitled to restrain disposition of assets that might be used for medical care, for pain and suffering. And this would, in effect, prevent the Alderson Reporting Company private bar from --  from practicing law unless it did so on a contingent basis.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but you're talking about probable cause. But --  but there's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The government can often show probable cause, and that's usually the basis for the indictment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Dreeben --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It takes the --  it - it establishes that right in the same way as the issue here, without counsel on the part of the defendant, because you --  I assume Kaley applies to untainted assets as well as untainted. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So add to the context of what Justice Breyer was concerned about. You not only can do that, you can do that without giving the defendant any type of hearing, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I thought --  I thought under Kaley, the defendant didn't have to be provided a --  a hearing with respect to the pretrial --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: --  seizure of assets.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Kaley was a question of tracing, because it was --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But you don't have any tracing problem here. As soon as he commits a crime that you say was worth $45 million, you can freeze $45 million worth of assets, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I respect that, and -- but -- but you agreed that these particular funds were untainted. I'm told by your adversary --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Dreeben, I think, you know, in essence your argument goes like this: You have Monsanto, you combine Monsanto with a -- a simple factual acknowledgment that money is fungible, and it gets you to a judgment in this case. You win, the petitioner loses. And -- and, you know, that's a fair, strong argument, if -- if one is comfortable with Monsanto. I mean, there is -- so I think I would just Alderson Reporting Company ask you, I mean, suppose the Court is just uncomfortable with the path we started down the road on in Monsanto? And you might be right that it just doesn't make sense to draw a line here, but it leaves you with a situation in which more and more and more we're depriving people of the ability to hire counsel of choice in complicated cases. And so what should we do with that intuition that Monsanto sent us down the wrong path?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, how -- I don't know how these things work. Let's say you get an order freezing the assets, and it's $10 million, and -- and the defendant comes into the court, whatever, and says, look, my lawyer is going to cost $100,000, one percent of the assets that are at issue here. Then you would argue, no, even though it's only a tiny fraction of what we're seizing, the Sixth Amendment doesn't even entitle him to one percent of the assets that might -- might end up being forfeitable?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How does it work? Like the -- you know, the daughter's tuition bill comes due, you know, and it's whoever -- you know, who knows how much these days, $60,000. And the defendant cannot Alderson Reporting Company pay that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, why was it -- why would it be -- if he can exercise equitable discretion for the daughter's tuition, why -- why not when the Sixth Amendment is at stake? And, you know, counsel of choice, it turns on that, it would seem to me that if there's going to be a case in which equitable discretion will be exercised, it ought to be in that situation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Can you get back -- you had two responses to my reading of the statute. I heard the Alderson Reporting Company first, and I didn't hear the second.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: By the way, let me -- let me remind you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But I want to say it, because maybe you can focus on this. We're in before the judge on a TRO. Our object of the TRO is to separate the assets that are not this man's from the assets that are this man's. So we do that separation. Now we say $10,000 is not his, it's the bank's. $15,000 or $10,000 over here is totally his; he's never been convicted of the crime. What's the government's interest? And why can't he take this other, once we've had the TRO --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- to separate it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know. It says restraining order --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- and my suggestion is we read those words "restraining order" as "temporary restraining order," which (3)(b), it seems to me, Alderson Reporting Company clearly permits, but we can get into that argument. I'll worry about that later.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I want to know what your second response was to that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I don't --  go ahead and finish.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I'm -- I'm troubled by this statute. I -- I can't understand the difference between (a) and (B). I don't think -- the issue was not raised in the cert petition, and I don't know whether it can be brought in with the Doctrine of Constitutional Avoidance, because it really has nothing to do with the Sixth Amendment. This would apply regardless of whether there's any Sixth Amendment issue in the case. But, having said that -- Mr. Srebnick can address those in rebuttal if he wishes to, but having said that, if (B) does not refer to a temporary form of relief, then -- which I understand to be your argument -- then I don't understand what (a) contributes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So what they can do is this? If we read this literally under (B), that Mr. Smith is indicted for a banking law violation, he has $100,000 of other people's money. The government can say that the order --  the restraining order of the Court prohibits his wife, any other client, the milk man, anyone in the world, from taking, not the $100,000 that belongs to the bank, but any other $100,000 that he got for any other purpose, I guess including his retirement fund, including no matter what. I mean, that is --  goes --  it seems to me that's what it says --  any other person from taking property of equivalent value, and he hasn't been convicted of anything.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, this is --  this is Alderson Reporting Company innocent money, the defendant's, not the money he obtained as a result of the violation. The money he didn't obtain, that's what this case is about.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Dreeben, you're taking Monsanto out of context, because 853, by its nature, was limited to tainted funds. This is the first statute if -- that I know of that permits the government to come in and take untainted funds. The incidence of the tainted funds concept was, you can't spend another person's money. You stole this money somehow, and you can't spend that money because it belongs to someone Alderson Reporting Company else. It really doesn't belong to you. But it's not until a judgment -- and this is what your adversary is trying to say -- that the money that's untainted, the money that -- or the property that he bought before this crime, this untainted property becomes yours. It's not until that moment, the judgment, that the property is forfeitable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You can't forfeit it beforehand. So now the issue is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, but -- but still the question becomes, is there a substantive difference, and I think Justice Breyer is expressing -- the problem with this, as Justice Kagan said, this intuitive sense, which is where do we draw this line?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Does the right to counsel have any meaning anymore?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Frankly, I expect within three to five years, if we rule in your favor, will be changed to have this same language.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Yes, but not pretrial.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But that's true of every judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Every judgment gives you a right to substitute property of some sort.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Dreeben --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: When did the -- when did the -- when was the first statute that allowed the government to restrain the expenditure of tainted funds? Does that go back a long time or --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And -- and the first time that Congress ever applied it to non-tainted property was what year?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And -- but just -- just to be clear, so that I understood your earlier answer, the consequence, the necessary consequence of your position is that any State in the union can provide for forfeiture or a freeze -- a freeze of assets pending trial in any assault and battery case, spousal abuse case, criminal negligence, date rape cases in order to make the victim whole, to pay for medical costs, to pay for pain and suffering, and can freeze those assets even if the consequences of that is that in most of those cases most people cannot afford counsel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's the consequence of your argument?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, and they're all cases in which the defendant has not been found guilty. And -- and in all those cases, I mean, all you have to do, all the governments have to do, all the State governments have to do, is provide for a fine and argue, then, well, unless we -- if we don't freeze the assets, there won't be money left to pay a fine. So this could apply -- I guess this is the point. This could apply to every crime on the books.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Have you seen -- have you seen the judgments in the fraud on the market cases? I mean, it isn't too tough in cases involving fraud on the market to find judgments of tens or hundreds of millions of dollars, I mean, judgments in fines after convictions, and that's what, I think, the question is. The principle of constitutional law that Alderson Reporting Company you're advocating would, in fact, permit the freezing of what might be paid afterwards in a fine which could be a huge amount before the person is convicted. Am I right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It goes to the Medicaid trust fund?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The --  will go to the victims?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Does that go to the victims in case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Dreeben, you're saying that your -- your view, your interpretation, your reading of the statute is the only tenable one, but if one took the view that Justice Breyer's interpretation, that restraining order means a temporary restraining order, or it was another interpretation put forth in the Americans for Forfeiture Reform brief, because if -- if a judge were to take the position that all of -- all three are plausible readings of the statute, but we'll pick the one that allows the defendant to have counsel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Dreeben, if I could go back to Justice Alito's questions about your interpretation of the statute, I think what Justice Alito was suggesting was that (a)(2)(A) would be completely subsumed by (a)(2)(B) on your interpretation, and I don't think that you got around to answering that question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: No, but in --  in just saying Alderson Reporting Company that, you're essentially saying, yes, (B) expands it out, meaning it covers everything that (A) covers and some more.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Do you think that there's any --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Go ahead.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Do you think that there's any way to read this statute such that it applies to people who wish to retain counsel as opposed to make other expenditures?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Srebnick, you have four minutes Alderson Reporting Company remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I don't want to use up your rebuttal time, but I do want to ask you two quick questions about the statute. First is: Did you raise anything about this in your cert petition? And the second is: Is there a way to limit this to the Sixth Amendment context?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: You didn't say anything about constitutional avoidance in your cert position, did you?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
